clinical_study.brief_title: Data-driven Shared Decision-making to Reduce Symptom Burden in Atrial Fibrillation
clinical_study.official_title: Data-driven Shared Decision-making to Reduce Symptom Burden in Atrial Fibrillation

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

brief_summary.textblock: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia with symptoms that directly impair health-related quality of life (HRQoL). While catheter ablation is routinely performed to reduce AF symptoms and improve HRQoL, the research community lack evidence about which symptoms for which patients are likely to improve. Ablations themselves may cause complications that lead to lower HRQoL. Shared decision-making (SDM) is a widely encouraged practice to navigate such complex choices by aligning treatment benefits and risks with the patient's stated values. However, no SDM interventions have focused explicitly on AF symptoms due to a lack of rigorous evidence about potential outcomes and the decision aids necessary to communicate those findings. In this K99/R00 application, the investigators propose to use "real-world evidence" drawn from electronic health records (EHRs) to characterize post-ablation symptom patterns, and display them in decision-aid visualizations to support SDM. In this project, the investigators will first use natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) to extract and analyze symptom data from narrative notes in EHRs. The investigators will also employ a rigorous, user-centered design protocol created during the Principal Investigator's post-doctoral work to develop decision-aid visualizations. In the clinical trial, the investigators will evaluate the feasibility of implementing these interactive decision-aid visualizations in clinical practice. The specific aim of the clinical trial is to evaluate the feasibility of putting the visualizations into clinical practice (n=75). The hypothesis is that patients will report low decisional conflict and decision regret and high satisfaction with their decision about whether to undergo an ablation or not.

detailed_description.textblock: This study is a single-group feasibility study evaluating decision aid visualizations which display common post-ablation symptom patterns as a tool for shared decision-making. The study design and sample size align with a recent feasibility study of a shared decision-making intervention focused on anticoagulant selection in AF. The primary outcomes of the study are decisional conflict, satisfaction, and regret. Secondary outcomes include health-related quality of life and reduction of symptoms. The investigators will measure symptoms both by patient report via mobile health application and by provider report via electronic health record. First, the investigators will recruit and enroll patients (n=75) who are scheduled for a consultation with an electrophysiology (EP) practice at NYP about undergoing ablation for atrial fibrillation. The investigators will screen eligible patients ahead of the scheduled consultation visit using electronic health records. Pending permissions from EP practice providers and IRB approval, the investigators will contact them prior to the visit to gauge interest, and ask them to arrive one hour early if interested. They will obtain informed consent upon arrival at the visit. Patients will first be screened for severe cognitive impairment prior to providing written informed consent. They will collect the following baseline surveys: demographics (including socioeconomic status), health literacy, subjective numeracy, graph Literacy, patient preferences for participation (Control Preference Scale), decision conflict (Decisional Conflict Scale), Medical Communication Competence Scale-Patient version, and Atrial Fibrillation Effect on QualiTy-of-Life (AFEQT) scale. Patients will also complete a baseline survey of their current symptoms using validated symptom scales (Canadian Cardiovascular Society-Severity of Atrial Fibrillation Symptoms scale, and Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System scales). All surveys will be collected using Research Electronic Data Capture (REDCap), a secure web application for building and managing online surveys and databases. The investigators will introduce the decision aid visualizations after consultation with clinical staff at the EP practice. After completing the clinical visits, participants will be invited to a private, quiet space in the practice to view the interactive decision aid visualizations displaying expected symptom patterns after ablation based on the patient's personal characteristics. The exact characteristics used to tailor visualizations will be determined during previous symptom pattern analyses. For example, if cluster analyses determine that symptom patterns differ by age group, the investigators will creating tailoring within symptom visualizations based on the patient's age group. Interactive visualizations will be developed in a secure web application and displayed on a tablet. Patients will be allowed to view and discuss decision aid visualizations for as long as they would like. Then, they will be equipped with the KardiaÂ® device, which records highly-accurate, single-lead ECGs and transmits to healthcare providers. The investigators will develop a thorough clinical protocol for monitoring and responding to potentially dangerous ECG strips that are transmitted through Kardia when the R00 application is finalized in Year 2 of the study. Participants will also complete the same validated symptom scales that they initially completed at baseline during the follow-up period using a mobile application developed by our team, "mi.Symptoms." This mobile application also runs through the REDCap infrastructure. They will be asked to self-monitor symptoms once per week using mi.Symptoms, and self-monitor heart rate and rhythm 4-7 times per week using Kardia. They will be asked to self-monitor for 12 weeks. After 12 weeks, participants will complete follow-up surveys using REDCap: Satisfaction with Decision Scale, Decision Regret Scale, and AFEQT questionnaire. They will also be invited to participate in exit interviews (30-60 minutes) to discuss their experiences. Interviews will be guided by the following constructs from the widely-used implementation science framework "RE-AIM": reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance. Interviews will be audio-recorded and transcribed verbatim. All materials will be kept in a locked cabinet or stored on an encrypted hard drive in my locked office at WCM. Quantitative data will first be assessed using standard, descriptive statistics. In addition to evaluating decision satisfaction and regret 12 weeks after initial ablation consultation, the investigators will evaluate changes in symptoms over time, using multiple growth models with random effects among intercepts and slopes, and identify clusters of symptom patterns using latent classes analysis. They will evaluate concordance between symptoms and heart rhythm to better understand associations between specific symptoms, or lack thereof, and heart rhythm, which is poorly understood in the literature currently. They will also evaluate decisional conflict and health-related quality of life (AFEQT) pre- and post-decision aid. Qualitative data will be analyzed using a general inductive approach. They will use the collected quantitative and qualitative data to complete an implementation analysis of predisposing, enabling, and reinforcing factors of implementing the decision-aid visualizations in clinical practice using RE-AIM. Finally, they will take advantage of patient-reported (mHealth) and provider-reported (i.e., EHR) symptoms collected simultaneously in this study to measure agreement between the two sources. The investigators will seek to identify whether differential EHR documentation patterns exist for underserved patient groups, which may be associated with disparities in symptom management.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This is a single arm feasibility study.

primary_outcome.measure: Decisional conflict assessed using the Decisional Conflict Scale
primary_outcome.description: Conflict about the decision to undergo atrial fibrillation will be assessed using the Decisional Conflict Scale on a scale of 0 (no decisional conflict) to 100 (extremely high decisional conflict).

primary_outcome.measure: Decision regret assessed using the Decisional Regret Scale
primary_outcome.description: Regret about the decision to undergo atrial fibrillation will be assessed using the Decision Regret Scale on a scale of 0 (no decision regret) to 100 (extremely high decision regret).

primary_outcome.measure: Decision satisfaction assessed using the Satisfaction with Decision Scale
primary_outcome.description: Satisfaction about the decision to undergo atrial fibrillation will be assessed using the Satisfaction with Decision Scale on a scale of 1 (low satisfaction) to 5 (high satisfaction).

secondary_outcome.measure: Post-ablation symptom burden assessed using the Atrial Fibrillation severity Scale (AFSS)
secondary_outcome.description: The severity of atrial fibrillation symptoms after an ablation will be assessed using the AFSS on a scale of 0 (no symptom burden) to 35 (extremely high symptom burden).

secondary_outcome.measure: Post-ablation health-related quality of life assessed using the Atrial Fibrillation Effect on QualiTy-of-Life (AFEQT) questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: Health-related quality of life after an ablation will be assessed using the AFEQT on a scale of 0 (complete disability) to 100 (high quality of life).

arm_group.description: Participants in this arm will view a shared decision-making tool while they are undergoing consultation to have an atrial fibrillation ablation.

intervention.description: Participants will use an interactive web page intended to aid patient decision-making (i.e., a decision aid) while undergoing consultation for atrial fibrillation ablation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ICD-10 diagnosis of paroxysmal AF
- Scheduled consultation at NYP to discuss catheter ablation
- Symptomatic AF at baseline
- Age 18 years and older
- Able to read and speak English
- Willing/able to provide informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Asymptomatic AF
- Severe cognitive impairment
- Major psychiatric illness
- Concomitant terminal illness that would preclude participation
